title: 107_s1584
content: The Act titled "Integrity of the United States Courts Act of 2001" allows for judicial review of binational panel decisions under the North American Free Trade Agreement Implementation Act. The "Integrity of the United States Courts Act of 2001" allows for judicial review of binational panel decisions under the North American Free Trade Agreement Implementation Act within 30 days after publication in the Federal Register. If a party alleges misinterpretation of US law, misconduct, bias, departure from procedure, or exceeding of powers by the panel, they can seek review in the Court of International Trade. If a binational panel exceeds its jurisdiction or fails to apply the correct standard of review, a party can appeal to the United States Court of International Trade. If a panel is not convened within 315 days of a request for review under article 1904, the requesting party can seek review in court. Within 315 days of the request, the requesting party can file an appeal of the antidumping or countervailing duty determination with the United States Court of International Trade. The Court will review the binational panel's decision and determine if any actions described in the appeal have been established, vacating the original panel decision if necessary. The Court of International Trade will vacate the original panel decision and enter judgment accordingly if actions are established. Decisions of the Court under this section are binding on the parties. If no panel is convened, the Court will review the investigating authority's determination to ensure compliance with article 1904. The Court of International Trade will vacate the investigating authority's determination if it is not in accordance with article 1904 or lacks legal and factual support. Decisions of the Court are binding on the parties involved. If a party files a notice of appeal, the Court has exclusive jurisdiction to review the determination. The Court of International Trade has exclusive jurisdiction over determinations related to goods from NAFTA countries, which are not subject to review by an extraordinary challenge committee. This jurisdiction applies to antidumping and countervailing duty determinations made by investigating authorities in the United States. The Court of International Trade has exclusive jurisdiction over determinations related to goods from NAFTA countries, including antidumping and countervailing duty determinations. Additionally, Sec. 404A addresses the review of binational panel determinations. Section 516A of the Tariff Act of 1930 is amended to include final determinations of binational panels under NAFTA and investigating authorities under the North American Free Trade Agreement Implementation Act. The Tariff Act of 1930 is amended to include final determinations of binational panels under NAFTA and investigating authorities under the North American Free Trade Agreement Implementation Act, including a new provision for review requested by a party or person under article 1904 of NAFTA. The amendments made by this Act apply to goods from Canada and Mexico under the North American Free Trade Agreement. The effective date is for final determinations of binational panels or investigating authorities published in the Federal Register after the enactment of this Act.
